head.title: Epitaph.11 First published in Poems (1794), p. 36; reprinted in City Gazette and Daily Advertiser [Charleston] (February 20, 1796).

lg.l: Stop, friends! or softly tread this holy ground,
And pass, with rev’rence, o’er the sacred bound,
Where low in earth the cold remains are laid
Of Elenor,22 Derivation of the Old French Alienor popularized by Eleanor of Acquitaine. a wise, and beauteous maid.
Truth flow’d than honey sweeter from her tongue,
And list’ning angels prais’d her when she sung.
Her wit and beauty all the young admir’d,
And age was with her matchless virtue fir’d.
Death had for once his mandate disobey’d,
Unwilling to arrest so sweet a maid;
But, judging life unworthy of the care
Of one so fit for Heav’n, he sent her there.
